articles.headline: With Engagement Rings, Love Meets Budget
articles.snippet: Arriving at the right amount to budget for an engagement ring is something that many young people continue to struggle with.
articles.abstract: Arriving at the right amount to budget for an engagement ring is something that many young people continue to struggle with.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ilona Kaprovsky, a 24-year-old New Yorker who works in finance, said she didn’t initially think she wanted a diamond as the centerpiece of her engagement ring — a lab-grown stone like a white sapphire, or even cubic zirconia, would be just fine. Besides, who would know the difference?

articles.headline: Retailers Ask: Where Did Teenagers Go?
articles.snippet: The competition for teenage dollars, at a time of high unemployment within that age group, spans from more stores to shop in to more tempting technology.
articles.abstract: The competition for teenage dollars, at a time of high unemployment within that age group, spans from more stores to shop in to more tempting technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Luring young shoppers into traditional teenage clothing stores has become a tough sell.

articles.headline: Snacks Laced With Marijuana Raise Concerns
articles.snippet: The popularity of edible marijuana has alarmed parents’ groups and others who say the highly concentrated snacks are increasingly landing in the hands of children too young to know the difference between pot brownies and regular ones.
articles.abstract: The popularity of edible marijuana has alarmed parents’ groups and others who say the highly concentrated snacks are increasingly landing in the hands of children too young to know the difference between pot brownies and regular ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — All day long, customers at LoDo Wellness Center, one of Colorado’s new recreational marijuana stores, reach into the refrigerator and pull out tasty ways to get high. They buy sparkling peach and mandarin elixirs, watermelon Dew Drops, and sleek silver bags of chocolate truffles, each one packed with marijuana’s potent punch.

articles.headline: Tech Rides Are Focus of Hostility in Bay Area
articles.snippet: Rising resentment against elite technology firms manifests itself in demonstrations at public bus stops in San Francisco, where private shuttle buses ferry engineers to work.
articles.abstract: Rising resentment against elite technology firms manifests itself in demonstrations at public bus stops in San Francisco, where private shuttle buses ferry engineers to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Like huge lumbering beasts, the luxury buses shuffle down Valencia Street.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Malia Wollan

articles.headline: Fund-Raising by G.O.P. Rebels Outpaces Party Establishment
articles.snippet: Underscoring a potential shift of power in the Republican Party, candidates are counting on outside groups critical of the leadership for campaign muscle.
articles.abstract: Underscoring a potential shift of power in the Republican Party, candidates are counting on outside groups critical of the leadership for campaign muscle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Insurgent conservatives seeking to pull the Republican Party to the right raised more money last year than the groups controlled by the party establishment, whose bulging bank accounts and ties to major donors have been their most potent advantage in the running struggle over the party’s future, according to new campaign disclosures and interviews with officials.

articles.headline: A Long Fight to Get What Was Theirs, in a 401(k)
articles.snippet: After a five-year battle, retirement account holders of a collapsed company can finally touch their money.
articles.abstract: After a five-year battle, retirement account holders of a collapsed company can finally touch their money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years, two articles in this space, assistance from the Labor Department and the Internal Revenue Service and prodding from one no-nonsense bankruptcy judge — that’s what it took for owners of the 401(k) plan sponsored by Penn Specialty Chemicals to gain access to their money last month.

articles.headline: Chasing Their Star, on YouTube
articles.snippet: The message to aspiring video makers on YouTube is clear, and seductive: Attract an audience, build your brand. But success, let alone stardom and wealth, remains elusive.
articles.abstract: The message to aspiring video makers on YouTube is clear, and seductive: Attract an audience, build your brand. But success, let alone stardom and wealth, remains elusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is 3 p.m., and outside another brilliant Los Angeles afternoon beckons. But Olga Kay has drawn her blinds, leaving her living room in a semidarkened haze.

articles.headline: Law Doesn’t End Revolving Door on Capitol Hill
articles.snippet: Former officials have little trouble passing through loopholes in laws intended to keep them from immediately lobbying their onetime colleagues.
articles.abstract: Former officials have little trouble passing through loopholes in laws intended to keep them from immediately lobbying their onetime colleagues.
articles.lead_paragraph: A top aide to a Republican congressman from Arizona helped promote a legislative plan to overhaul the nation’s home mortgage finance system. Weeks after leaving his government job, he reappeared on Capitol Hill, now as a lobbyist for a company poised to capitalize on the plan.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Ben Protess

articles.headline: With Fortune Falling, a 1 Percent Divorce
articles.snippet: Liz and Kent Swig swiftly scaled the heights of Manhattan real estate and social life. Then the market’s walls closed in.
articles.abstract: Liz and Kent Swig swiftly scaled the heights of Manhattan real estate and social life. Then the market’s walls closed in.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is a story of marriage and money in the 16-room, five-and-a-half-bath duplex world of luxury Manhattan real estate.

articles.headline: In China, ‘Once the Villages Are Gone, the Culture Is Gone’
articles.snippet: Rapid urbanization in China means village life, the bedrock of Chinese culture, is rapidly vanishing, and with it, traditions and history.
articles.abstract: Rapid urbanization in China means village life, the bedrock of Chinese culture, is rapidly vanishing, and with it, traditions and history.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Once or twice a week, a dozen amateur musicians meet under a highway overpass on the outskirts of Beijing, carting with them drums, cymbals and the collective memory of their destroyed village. They set up quickly, then play music that is almost never heard anymore, not even here, where the steady drone of cars muffles the lyrics of love and betrayal, heroic deeds and kingdoms lost.

articles.headline: Severe Drought Has U.S. West Fearing Worst
articles.snippet: With no sign of rain, 17 rural California communities providing water to 40,000 people are in danger of running out within 60 to 120 days.
articles.abstract: With no sign of rain, 17 rural California communities providing water to 40,000 people are in danger of running out within 60 to 120 days.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The punishing drought that has swept California is now threatening the state’s drinking water supply.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Ian Lovett

articles.headline: Super Bowl Underscores the Big Business of Must-See, Live TV
articles.snippet: At a time of atomization and endless special-interest hobbit holes, big live television events like the Super Bowl fulfill our need for something, anything, in common.
articles.abstract: At a time of atomization and endless special-interest hobbit holes, big live television events like the Super Bowl fulfill our need for something, anything, in common.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a fact of modern life that the mass has gone out of media, with television ratings reflecting that each of us is building our own little campfire on our phone, tablet and big screen at a time and place of our choosing.

articles.headline: Building a Better Battery
articles.snippet: As tech companies focus on small, wearable devices, they have encountered an obstacle: Battery technology is largely stuck in the 20th century.
articles.abstract: As tech companies focus on small, wearable devices, they have encountered an obstacle: Battery technology is largely stuck in the 20th century.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The next breakthrough smartphone, or maybe the one after that, might not have a traditional battery as its sole source of power. Instead, it could pull energy from the air or power itself through television, cellular or Wi-Fi signals.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Imax Faces a Threat in China
articles.snippet: Not only could competitors in China cut into its potential market share there, but Imax has charged in several courts that the Chinese system relies on technology that was blatantly stolen from its offices in Canada.
articles.abstract: Not only could competitors in China cut into its potential market share there, but Imax has charged in several courts that the Chinese system relies on technology that was blatantly stolen from its offices in Canada.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “We’ve got the future under control,” contends OmniCorp, the giant technology corporation in “RoboCop,” a blockbuster remake set for release by Sony Pictures and MGM next month.

articles.headline: The Middle Class Is Steadily Eroding. Just Ask the Business World.
articles.snippet: The post-recession reality is that the customer base for businesses that appeal to the middle class is shrinking as the top tier pulls even further away.
articles.abstract: The post-recession reality is that the customer base for businesses that appeal to the middle class is shrinking as the top tier pulls even further away.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Manhattan, the upscale clothing retailer Barneys will replace the bankrupt discounter Loehmann’s, whose Chelsea store closes in a few weeks. Across the country, Olive Garden and Red Lobster restaurants are struggling, while fine-dining chains like Capital Grille are thriving. And at General Electric, the increase in demand for high-end dishwashers and refrigerators dwarfs sales growth of mass-market models.

articles.headline: Libya’s Cache of Toxic Arms All Destroyed
articles.snippet: The United States and Libya in the past three months have discreetly destroyed what both sides say were the remnants of Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi’s arsenal of chemical arms.
articles.abstract: The United States and Libya in the past three months have discreetly destroyed what both sides say were the remnants of Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi’s arsenal of chemical arms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as the international effort to destroy Syria’s vast chemical weapons stockpile lags behind schedule, a similar American-backed campaign carried out under a cloak of secrecy ended successfully last week in another strife-torn country, Libya.

articles.headline: Battles Loom in Many States Over What to Do With Budget Surpluses
articles.snippet: Unexpectedly robust revenues from taxes and other sources are filling state coffers, prompting battles over what to do with the newfound money.
articles.abstract: Unexpectedly robust revenues from taxes and other sources are filling state coffers, prompting battles over what to do with the newfound money.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a year when three dozen governors are up for election, unexpectedly robust revenues from taxes and other sources are filling most state coffers, creating surpluses not seen in years and prompting statehouse battles over what to do with the money.

articles.headline: Newly Wary, Shoppers Trust Cash
articles.snippet: After disclosures about credit and debit card breaches at several major retailers, some shoppers are making the effort to use cash in lieu of cards.
articles.abstract: After disclosures about credit and debit card breaches at several major retailers, some shoppers are making the effort to use cash in lieu of cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like dieters vowing to trade cupcakes for carrots, a number of American shoppers are making a new pledge: cash only.

articles.headline: After Scandal, SAC Capital Begins to Fade to Black
articles.snippet: Steven A. Cohen’s hedge fund is completing plans to change its corporate structure by mid-March, according to people briefed on the matter, an effort that comes after SAC pleaded guilty to insider trading.
articles.abstract: Steven A. Cohen’s hedge fund is completing plans to change its corporate structure by mid-March, according to people briefed on the matter, an effort that comes after SAC pleaded guilty to insider trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAC Capital Advisors, synonymous with an insider trading scandal that has consumed the hedge fund industry, will soon cease to exist as Wall Street has known it.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson
